bibl.title: Letter from A. W. Mellon to Mabel H. Lazear, September 25, 1931

div1.p: Congress authorizes presentation of gold medal to widow in recognition of high public service of late husband.

div1.head: Letter from A. W. Mellon to Mabel H. Lazear, September 25, 1931
div1.opener:
WALTER M. BRIGGS
74 TUNNEL ROAD
BERKELEY, CALIFORNIA
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
Washington
September 25, 1931
Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear,
6 Oak Vale Avenue,
Berkeley, Calif.
Dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
The Act of Congress of February 28, 1929, authorized
the Secretary of the Treasury to cause to be struck a gold medal
in recognition of the high public service of Major Walter Reed
and those associated with him in the discovery of the cause and
means of transmission of yellow fever. The Act further
directed that the Secretary of the Treasury present such medal to
each of such persons as shall be living and posthumously to repre-
sentatives of each of such persons as shall have died.

In accordance with the authority granted, I have the honor
to present this medal to you as the widow of the late Mr. Jesse W.
Lazear and transmit it herewith as a token of the grateful appre
ciation of your country for the services rendered by your husband.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, A. W. Mellon
Secretary of the Treasury.
